column4: Open Science is a paradigm, within which scientists, academies, institutions, agencies, and students share their research ideas, progress, methods, analysis, results, and data openly, freely, and without reservation. Open Science enables us as a society to push science forward, building on each other and with each other to reach scientific breakthroughs more efficiently and that would otherwise be unattainable through individual effort.

column4:
I think open science implies: 

1. Transparency in data collection process (well-documented protocols) and analysis, i.e. transparency of the ecological evidence. This also includes, documentation and communication of uncertainty (and certainty). 

2. Make data available for re-use. Adequate documentation.

3. Proper dataauthor recognition. I think that this is fundamental to achieve open science, that the intellectual rights behind data collection and curation are given due credit (it is not only the funders who have 'data rights'). Data collection respond to research questions and there is professional know-how involved in data collection.

column16:
First, fees that should be payed for publishing in some Open Access journals. There are, however, other OA journals completely fee of charge, but they are often of low impact factor. 

Second, I cannot put my data to be open access immediately  after being collected because me and my students must use them for publishing scientific papers which will justify the funds we got from the funding source. However, many scientific journals, after accepting your paper, require original data of the study to be deposit in some of open access data bases.
column17: When stared to think about climate change in my surroundings, it was difficult to get meteorological data because state agency asked to be payed for the data formation and export. So, thanks to that highly impacted open access peer reviewed journal, we found and used the data we needed so badly.

column4:
I don't have a succinct or thought out definition of open science. In my mind, two core concepts are relevant, 1) that the science is open for access, also by non-professionals that don't have traditional access to papers through a research institutions subscription, and 2) that the science is open to scrutiny, which in most cases requires access to data or mock data and a sufficiently detailed description of the analysis steps, which in most cases means analysis scripts. Both these aspects should theoretically be satisfied in "traditional science", but often is not, or is unfeasible in practice. Open science seems to have a lot to do with easing these two types of "access".

I'm sure there are other facets to the term. Maybe this will clear up after the workshop.
column15: "Use open code" is ambiguous. Open source software in general or analysis algorithms authored by researchers?    Don't know what open education tools are. I use open software every day. I prefer to use it whenever I can.    I have access to most journals through work, so I'm not aware of when I read open papers.

column30:
The research is probably not reproduced exactly as it was first performed as often as you'd think.

I've worked on datasets that have been to large to share, or not possible to share due to rights issues. You could create perhaps smaller fake datasets that lets anyone run through the steps of the analysis, without reproducing it exactly. 

Sometimes we also work in databases where it's not so easy to share data and code. Well, that's not true. I guess I'm just not used to it. I guess you could in principle share a database dump and database scripts.

column4:
Open Science is the vision of contributing to scientific knowledge by keeping the information accessible and open, including all the policies, standards, technical and practical solutions for sharing the information completely and easily. 

Besides making available freely scientific articles and published content, good practices should allow getting access to the data used to reach scientific results, together with the tools used for analyzing data.

Data should be shared following the FAIR principles being Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable. It implies using standards for structuring and formatting data, standards for metadata, suitable web protocols, open source software and applications.

Reproducing research outcomes should be easy and all the tools and needed information provided. 

Ideally, Open Science should also facilitate and promote increased participation in scientific activities from non experts, like in citizens science.
column16: Often data owners are still reluctant in sharing their information
column17: My daily work. Getting involved in the community. reading about it. Finding Open Science information
column18: Daily professional activity

column4:
Open Science is a science practice (i.e. a way of doing sciences) aimed at transparency, honesty, fairness and sharing. I'd define it as a practice that:

1. extends the principles of openness and FAIR-ness to the whole scientific research cycle
2. has honesty, ethics, transparency, equality & fairness at its core.
3. empowering researchers.
4. giving credit where its due
5. building effective collaborations.
6. improves science communication
7. provides value for money, particularly for public funds.

column4: I define open science as a transparent, shareable and accessible science. I can't currently write how it pertains to my work as I am unemployed but when I was studying at the university I know that we as students had struggles with getting adequate literature for our seminars and presentations due to expensive research papers. At first that appeared normal but as I gave it more thought I realized how restrictive this is for people who want to do proper research with the available literature stuck behind a paywall. When I hear words "open science" I immediately imagine a platform which has data that comprises not just of published data but data currently being used for the research. That way ideas, notes and methodology can be shared through the platform and also get a feedback from other researchers therefore reducing the probability of errors and research misconduct. Also the available data for a relevant research could constantly be reused for other research and increase reproducibility overall.
column16: I can't speak from the experience but I would say fear of data being stolen or misused and no acknowledgement for the particular research.
column17: I would say the transparency of the research. Knowing that research is publicly available at all stages and subject to opinions with as much as constructive feedback possible. Being able to share the data and reuse the data. And since I am interested in spatial ecology and species distribution models, being able to use the code suitable for my research from open science platform which means more efficiency and faster execution of related tasks. Consequentally all of the aforementioned speeds up the process of research-based decision making on nature management and biodiversity which is what a nature researcher should strive for.
column18: I am interested in how can open science be easily implemented in the researcher's life without being concerned about possible liabilities that comes with the research and also how to integrate data in research from open science sources.

column4: Open Science can be broadly summarized as aiming to promote integrity, repeatability, and transparency across all aspects of scientific research including: open access to publications, open data underlying research, open source code and data processing, and increasingly the broader concept of open reproducible research. These practices in addition to the FAIR principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reproducible), are fundamental in my role trying to link primary research to evidence synthesis and large scale modelling efforts - as the availability of open scientific data is critical. Furthermore, as an early career researcher these practices are important to be aware of as Open Science principles are becoming more prevelent within the scientific community, impacting everything from scientific publication via funding agencies to institutional and national research policies.
column16:
As an early career researcher, your ability to publish open access is limited by your lab group funding and priorities. With many projects, funding was applied for prior to the mass movement towards Open Science, and thus in-built funding for publishing Open Access may not always be possible. This is also entangled with managing publication priorities from co-authors, i.e. open access vs the percieved impact of a journal.

Also linked to research group culture - is the existing use of Open Source software, i.e. R, for analysis, allowing for the publication of Open Source Code. In some prior workplaces, propriatary software was prioritized, and thus scope for this is limited. On a data basis, one of the biggest hurdles is the sense of 'ownership' of data, particularly for large scale, labour intensive, or long-term datasets. In academia the 'publish or perish' culture, has led to fears of 'scooping', meaning many projects may be unwilling to share data until they feel they have had the opportunity to fully utilize it, or worry about authorship rights later on.
column17: Engaging with discussion groups and organizations focused on Open Science principles has enable me to have a broader appreciation for the complexity of the issue. With many multi-author, multi-national collaborations underway, a great appreciation for Open Science principles in general has become clear. Furthermore, working in different research groups, where emphasis on open coding, and data availability is more strong has made seeing pathways for engaging in FAIR practices less overwelming, as basic infrastructure and processes are already in place.
column18: I have previously attended the Evidence Synthesis Hackathon, organized by Neal Haddaway and Martin Westgate - this was an enlightening experience where efforts focused around a) developing new open source coding solutions to evidence synthesis issues (and thus the availability of data), and b) discussions on how we need Open Science to engage and link primary researchers with evidence synthesists. These skills and discussions, in addition with my position, linking field research (often via primary literature or contributes to trait databases) into land surface modelling, makes Open Science discusssions incredible relevant - the fact this is also located in Norway, and talks about local iniatives as well, is pertinent for me, being based here currently. Furthermore, I am keenly interesting in higher education, and I see opportunities for Open Science principles to be taught more widely during this education phase, ensuring early career researchers are equipped with the skills and competences they need to succeed in the future.

column4: I would define Open Science as science in which all stages are transparent. I.e. the data itself is openly accessible to anyone, the methods used for analysing/interpreting the data are described/published in a way that makes them reproducible, and results are published as "Open Access" (or in other was that makes them accessible to anyone)
column16: I have yet to be directly hindered. Potentially by time limitation
column17: My institution encourages publishing in Open Access journals by covering publication fees
column18: A general interest in Open Science, future career paths, relevance to current research

column4: I would define Open Science, in the immediate sense, as a way of conducting research in a manner that is transparent (i.e. showcasing/sharing how you are doing your research), however this should extend past just sharing your research and it should also include creating and cultivating a research environment that is open and inclusive to all. Within my work the aspect of reproducibility (particularly code-sharing) is something that I place particular value on
column16: Awareness of the concept/spaces/platforms that are available and facilitate cultivating an 'open' research workflow. In addition to this collaborating with colleagues that are 'hesitant' to engage with some of the platforms available sometimes disrupts the intended workflow.
column17: Being involved in a course that implemented (and showcased) various elements of a 'Open Science' workflow, this helped foster an understanding and appreciation of Open Science. In addition, working in a lab that has an active Open Science policy means that it is expected (and facilitated) that my work be conducted in a manner that aligns with FAIR and Open Science principles
column18: Although I am enthusiastic about Open Science I feel like there are elements/tools that I am not yet familiar with and believe that this workshop will help highlight/showcase some new approaches to OS both as a learning tool but also as a potential teaching tool in the future.
column30: If I could I would have put everything under 'Extremely important' but there are some things I value a bit more than others ;-)

column4: Open science to me means that all aspects of the scientific process are accessible to everyone. This means that results should be published open access, but also that asking research questions, collecting data, and the analyses should be open for the public. Citizen Science (in it's broadest form) is an example of open science, as are several research programs from large funders where funding becomes available for research questions posed by the general public.
column16: Initially it was a lack of knowledge on how and where I could share code and data. Now I have found good work flows for making my data and code available through GitHub and archiving through Zenodo which works really well.
column17: The growing movement of researchers making tools available for making my science open.
column18: The fact that I work using open data and citizen science in Sweden and Norway and it is important to be up to date on the developments in both countries.

column4:
Open science is the ideal of free and accessible availability for everyone to all conponents of the scientific cycle. Open science entails open education, open research protocols, open methodologies, open data, open code, open data management and analysis, open research publication opportunities, open research readership opportunities ("open access"), open data syntehsis, open science-policy interface, and an open research funding and open science system, science policy and science management.

Open science does *not* compromise qualiy control, on contratry, it enables quality control and oversigth over the fulfillment of research ethical and other standards.  

 

Open publicaiton does not mean that everyone has the *right* to publish, but that if the quality is there, everyone *can*, irrespective of means and institutional affiliation.

We are very far from 'open' in today's scientific community and science-policy interface, as some aspects of 'open' (e.g., open access to read) may compromise others (e.g., open publication oppotunities for everyone).
column16:
• time!
  • mostly, that, actually...
  • funding (for open access publiaction of non-project funded results)
  • available, convenient, impactful (enough) platforms for effectively sharing data and other open science products (protocols, etc)
  • most of the research I read/use is paywalled (so open access is of limted usage, so far)
  • concerns over fairness and accessibility (publishing your research, if of sufficient quality, should be an opportunity for all, not just the well off)
  • concerns over predatory publishing (publishing should *not* be something you can just pay your way into - I worry that predatory journals will / are consideralby harming the integrity of science
column17:
• availability of new open tools and pipelines
  • colleagues who have advocated and made available open methods, code, data, protocols
  • realization that being 'open' benefits me (as well as the world)
column18:
• learing more about open practices in aplied ecology
  • opportunitites to help foster healthy open science in  ecology in Norway
  • opportunities to help make research data and results available to nature conservation and management

column4: transparency and reproducibility of research methods, adaptability of research methods and data for different purposes, access to knowledge and scientific processes.
column16: Feeling inadequate in terms of coding ability - and being inadequate in coding ability (e.g. not knowing how to use github, and many of the resources I found to learn were written by geeks and not so intelligible, similarly it taking a few attempts before I could successfully build an R package). Also cost - for open access publishing. But mostly time - time to learn how to do things, learn about new databases, the extra time it takes to write metadata and document code properly.
column17: Online resources that are well written for relative beginners. User friendly platforms (e.g. OSF) that allow integration of multiple people from multiple institutions, and multiple types of files.
column18: I think I was coerced by my supervisor... and the opportunity to learn new tools and techniques in-person.
column30: I mostly work on trade-offs in environmental spheres, so this means potential conflict arenas. I need lots of data from different sources, many different modelling techniques, and I need my methods to be transparent and reproducible, to give validity to my modelling.

column4: Data, analyses and publication are FAIR, and not behind any paywall or mandatory login. As a result, research is replicable for anyone.
column16: Third party code, which will be opened but is under review by that third party
column17: Intrinsic motivation, contractual agreements
column18: I'm part of the organization. And FAIR is the way forward
